Obligation.origin: [held that the amendment did not unconstitutionally impair the s of contracts " Davis v. American Family Mut. Ins. Co. , 521 N.W.2d 366 (1994)"]

1.definition: any of the obligations binding different obligors to separate performances for one obligee

2.definition: any of the obligations binding an obligor to separate performances for different obligees

3.definition: what one is obligated to do, satisfy, or fulfill

sub_terms.a: a commitment to pay a particular amount of money [does not create a debt, liability, or other , legal or moral ", 650 So. 2d 14 (1995)"]an amount owed in such a commitment
sub_terms.b: a duty arising from law, contract, or morality [had a legal as an employer] [a contractual ]

4.definition: a relationship that binds one party to a performance (as a payment or transfer) or nonperformance for another party see also,,
4.note: An obligation under civil law may arise by operation of law, naturally, or by contract or other declaration of will. The elements of an obligation are: the parties, an object, the relationship by virtue of which one party is bound to perform for the other's benefit, and, in the case of conventional obligations, a cause.

conditional obligation.definition: an obligation that is dependent on an uncertain event

conventional obligation.definition: an obligation taking the form of a contract

heritable obligation.definition: an obligation that may be enforced by the successor of the obligee or against the successor of the obligor

natural obligation.definition: an obligation arising from moral duty that is implied but not enforceable by the law

solidary obligation.definition: an obligation under which any of two or more obligors can be held liable for the entire performance (as payment of a debt)
solidary obligation.note: Solidary obligation is similar to joint and several liability in common law.
